metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (AV-14TH;3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 2.5 m, 8 m in west of tower), four-component radiometer (PIR&PSP; 12 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (IRTC3; 12 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (LI190SB; 12 m, towards south, vertically upward; another four photosynthetically active radiation, PQS-1; two above the plants (12 m) and two below the plants (0.3 m), towards south, each with one vertically downward and one vertically upward), soil heat flux (HFP01SC; 3 duplicates with G1 below the vegetation; G2 and G3 between plants, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (TCAV; -0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_3 m, WD_5 m, WD_10 m, WD_15 m, WD_20 m, WD_30m, and WD_40 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/ (s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2, and Gs_3, between plants) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content), above the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2022-6-10 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection methods used for observing meteorological elements in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Concept Completion.Answer: eddy covariance system, scintillometer, automatic weather stations

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the observational datasets from oasis–desert systems, such as energy and carbon fluxes, typically collected?
Concept Completion.Answer: middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to gather energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems is the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, supplemented by automatic weather stations that observe a range of hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when conducting ecological observations in arid and semi-arid inland river basins?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced in conducting ecological observations in arid and semi-arid inland river basins is the ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrence of dust storms.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that includes long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas is the one reported in the study area of the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, which comprises energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters, freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main characteristics of the meteorological elements observed in the Heihe River Basin?
Feature Specification.Answer: wind speed and direction at seven different heights, air temperature and relative humidity at seven different heights, air pressure, precipitation, four-component radiation, surface radiation temperature, average soil temperature, soil heat flux, soil moisture, soil temperature at various depths, photosynthetically active radiation both above and within the canopy

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key challenges faced in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems?
Feature Specification.Answer: ecological environment degradation, drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, frequent dust storms

What is the number of layers at which wind speed and direction sensors are placed in the meteorological observation system?

Definition.Question: What is an 'eddy covariance system' in the context of data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a method used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems. It is part of the suite of observational datasets used in studies of these areas.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying principles can be inferred from the data collection techniques used in observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection techniques, which include the use of eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, suggest a focus on capturing precise, continuous measurements that can track small-scale changes in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. These methods highlight the importance of high temporal resolution and the integration of various environmental parameters to understand the dynamics of oasis-desert ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of data collection for sustainable development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance is vital to achieve sustainable oasis development, as it supports ecological security and the socioeconomic stability of arid regions. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange through long-term observations helps to protect these delicate ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of employing a multi-layered sensor approach for collecting meteorological and soil data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a multi-layered sensor approach allows for a comprehensive understanding of the vertical gradients of atmospheric and soil parameters, which can lead to insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems, thereby supporting sustainable development and ecological stability.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of long-term observational datasets influence the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of long-term observational datasets enhances the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange by providing continuous and consistent data over time, which is critical for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and contributes to achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind establishing a comprehensive observation network for surface processes in arid and semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for quantitatively understanding the interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems, which are significant for protecting ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development in oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale for using a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The rationale is to provide comprehensive data involving energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, which help in recognizing oasis–desert interactions and support sustainable development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedures for setting up a meteorological gradient observation system within an agricultural area to monitor various climatic factors?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key procedures include installing sensors for wind speed and direction at multiple heights (3m to 40m), placing a barometer at 2m, a rain gauge at 2.5m height, and positioning radiation instruments at 12m. Soil temperature and moisture sensors are embedded at various depths, and different orientations and distances from the tower are considered for precise measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can data quality control be effectively implemented in a long-term meteorological observation network to ensure accuracy and reliability?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality control can be implemented by ensuring a consistent number of daily data points (e.g., 144 for every 10-minute interval), marking missing data with specific values, removing duplicate records, deleting data beyond physical or instrumental limits, and highlighting questionable data in red. Consistent formatting for date and time is also crucial.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps are involved in collecting and processing hydrometeorological and soil parameter data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodological steps involve acquiring data through instruments like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for fluxes, and automatic weather stations for meteorological variables. Data processing includes collecting, processing, archiving, and sharing the data, with specific emphasis on capturing gradients of air temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, and maintaining a regular data collection schedule.

Enablement.Question: How do automated weather stations facilitate the collection of comprehensive hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Automated weather stations facilitate the collection of comprehensive hydrometeorological data by integrating various sensors that measure radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture with a 10-minute average period.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for establishing long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Establishing long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions requires conditions such as the deployment of land surface flux and meteorological stations to continuously monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, alongside the support of robust data processing and quality control procedures.

Expectation.Question: What reasons might contribute to the expectation that oasis–desert areas require specific data collection methods for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies?
Expectation.Answer: Oasis–desert areas have unique ecological dynamics, with oases supporting a significant portion of the population in arid regions and playing a crucial role in ecological stability. The complex interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges necessitate specialized data collection methods, such as using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for capturing turbulent flux data.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using multiple layers of sensors at different heights for collecting meteorological data in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Using multiple layers of sensors at different heights is effective for capturing vertical profiles of meteorological parameters such as wind speed, air temperature, and humidity, which are crucial in understanding energy exchange processes in arid regions. This approach enables detailed analysis of atmospheric conditions, providing valuable insights into microclimatic variations and enhancing the precision of data collected.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the challenges involved in maintaining long-term observation networks in oasis–desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining long-term observation networks in oasis–desert systems is challenging due to harsh environmental conditions, including extreme temperatures and dust storms, which can affect equipment reliability. Additionally, logistical challenges related to site accessibility and the need for consistent data quality control and archiving over extended periods add complexity to such endeavors.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how do you perceive the potential benefits of integrating hydrometeorological and soil data in understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological and soil data is highly beneficial for understanding oasis–desert interactions as it provides comprehensive insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes. This integration helps in assessing the ecological and agricultural stability of these systems, supporting sustainable development and ecological security goals.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively capture energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Observational datasets from oasis–desert systems include long-term measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These are acquired using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, supplemented by hydrometeorological data observed from automatic weather stations, which provide information on radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles.

Assertion.Question: I am unsure about the challenges faced when collecting data in arid and semiarid inland river basins.
Assertion.Answer: These regions face ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges complicate data collection efforts.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets are managed and shared in large-scale environmental observations.
Assertion.Answer: Data management involves data collection, processing, and archiving for sharing. For oasis–desert areas, datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations are made freely available from platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, ensuring accessibility for further research.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline a comprehensive data collection strategy for observing meteorological and hydrometeorological parameters in arid and semi-arid regions, incorporating both natural and artificial systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive data collection strategy would involve setting up multiple observation points with automatic weather stations to record data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Additionally, using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers could provide detailed measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These systems should collect data at regular intervals, such as every 10 minutes or half-hourly, to ensure a robust dataset. Supplementary data on vegetation and soil parameters should also be collected to provide context and enhance the understanding of the observed interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a method for expanding existing datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions to include additional parameters that could enhance understanding of these ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand existing datasets, additional parameters such as detailed soil nutrient profiles, microbial activity, and more granular vegetation data (e.g., species diversity, phenology) could be included. Employing remote sensing technologies like aerial drones equipped with multispectral sensors could provide high-resolution spatial data on vegetation and surface temperature. Integrating these new data sources with existing datasets can offer a more comprehensive view of the ecosystem processes. Collaborative efforts with local research institutions could also facilitate the inclusion of socio-economic data, linking ecological observations with human impact assessments.
